«+» blood glucose fine. Liver function, kidney function, normal...
MARTIN SIXSMITH, mid-40s, sits listening to someone (as y unseen), as a series of test results are read out to him.
Platelet count normal, haemoglobin levels normal, blood pressure, 131 over 92...

(Pouncing on this) Isn't that high? Now we see ROBERT, Martin’s doctor, mid-50s, chipper. Caption: London, 2002 ROBERT looks up from a folder of results he’s reading and familiar with Martin’s hypochondria, ignores the question

Weight fine... could do with losing a centimetre or two off your waist. Stool sample outstanding... MARTIN finally perks up at this, raises his eyebrow, plea with himself. ROBERT notices this... ROBERT (cont’d) No, that means you haven't provided one yet.
Oh right, yes. No, I’d remember.
(As he shuts the file) Did you think it didn’t stink or something? (Little smile from MARTIN) There’s basically nothing wrong with you Martin. Um... do you run?
Well... I walk a lot.
Try running.
(Worried) Do I need to?
I do it. Good for your body and... good for your head - Kate says you think you’re mildly depressed? MARTIN shrugs.
I got fired. I’m unemployed.
But it wasn’t your fault, was it?
That’s probably why I’m depressed -— I was sacked for saying something I didn't say! Silence.
Try running-
I said the exact opposite of what I was sacked for! Another silence. ROBERT tries a different tack:
What are you working on at the moment?
(Beat) I was... thinking of writing a book.
That’s good. What about?
Russian history.
(Beat) What makes you think it’s depression and not just feeling sorry for yourself? Silence.
Doesn’t have to be Russian history - could be something else...

Nineteen year old PHILOMENA LEE, pretty, dark haired, wea lovely summer dress, that same crucifix glinting in the sunshine. She picks her way wide-eyed, through the crowd; bright lights, the air filled with noise and excitement.
You looking for something? YOUNG PHILOMENA turns to see JOHN, early 20s, with a gro his FRIENDS by a beer tent, smiling at her.
No. She walks off, he follows.

I haven’t seen yous any place. Where are you from? JOHN follows her past the brightly coloured stalls, still cradling his glass of beer. JOHN (cont'd) Are you from Limerick then? YOUNG PHILOMENA stops by a hoop-la, excited by the attent but trying to play it - at least a little - cool. JOHN (cont'd) Here have a drink of my beer. He holds out his beer. She shakes her head. JOHN (cont'd) Go on take it - what’s the matter with you. She relents, takes the glass from him and takes a swig. S doesn’t like the taste. JOHN (cont'd) I like your dress. Did you make it yourself?
(Indignant ) No I bought it in a shop. Anyway, me auntie told me I’m not to talk to strange men like you.

Sure I’m not strange. Look at yer man over there... He nods to a ruddy-faced man, early 20s, (DECLAN), his an swinger trousers tied up with string, buying a toffee app from a stall and looking at his purchase with reverence. JOHN (cont'd) Has a rope for a belt. He should put some jam on his shoes and invite his trousers down for tea. YOUNG PHILOMENA giggles.  JOHN (cont'd) That’s who your auntie was talking about.
I wouldn’t mind a bite of his toffee apple.

You want a toffee apple? (Calls out) Declan! DECLAN looks over, smiles, revealing one and a half teeth JOHN (cont'd) Come over here. DECLAN, a simple soul, dutifully troops over. JOHN (cont'd) Do you want this beer? There’s about half a pint left. DECLAN nods enthusiastica JOHN nods to the toffee apple, a single bite out of it. JOHN (cont'd) I‘1l swap you.

JOHN and YOUNG PHILOMENA kiss passionately in a gap betwe two stalls, hidden from view. JOHN brushes his hand down side of her breast to her waist, then slips down to her bottom. The shot CONTINUES to her hand; OOV she moans softly... she drops the toffee apple she’s holding.

INT. FRONT ROOM, JANE’S HOUSE - DUSK CLOSE on PHILOMENA LEE, an elderly Irish lady, watching T the blue light playing on the lenses of her glasses. Thou distracted, distant with her thoughts, she is half paying attention to a news report on TV about the purchase, for forty nine and a half million pounds, of a painting of by Rubens - ‘The Slaughter of The Innocents’. Her daughter JANE, dark-haired, late 30s, enters in a hur She pulls a coat over an outfit of black skirt and white (like a receptionist in Soho House might wear).
Right, just go up and turn their lights out in half an hour.
Doesn’t she know you’ve got a proper job?
I’m just helping her out tonight - she’s short staffed. The painting flashes up on TV, depicting bloody biblical carnage.

(Distracted, talking to the TV not JANE) Fancy spending all that money on a God awful thing like that? If it was me I’d take everyone to the Brent Cross shopping centre and I’d say you can have one thing, whatever you like - two things. JANE drops her keys in her bag, she’s ready to go:
So I'll be back before midnight. Okay? PHILOMENA doesn’t respond. JANE (cont'd) Mum? JANE sees her mother is looking down at something in her hands.
And I'd get myself a brand new Nissan Micro automatic...

Mother? She sees PHILOMENA is clutching a small, old, black and w photo with serrated edges. She is late for work but begin sense something is badly wrong. JANE (cont'd) What is it mum? What’s the matter? PHILOMENA looks up at JANE, tears in her eyes. JANE nods the photo. JANE (cont'd) What's that? PHILOMENA’S hands start to shake as, slowly, she holds it
(Voice barely a whisper) It’s his birthday. He would have been fifty today...
(Beat) Who?

YOUNG PHILOMENA, her sweaty face contorted as she screams in agony. She lays back on a bed, legs in stirrups, in an improvised delivery room above the chapel. She’s in the advanced stages of labour - but there are complications. As two OLDER NUNS look on impotently, wringing their hand she is attended by a younger nun just a few years older t her. This is Sister ANUNCIATA, pale, red-haired, terrifie She looks at a pair of forceps in a metal bowl and knows should attempt to use them - but they seem monstrous, medieval. YOUNG PHILOMENA grabs ANUNCIATA’S hand as anoth spasm grips her body.
Don’t let them put him in the ground. It’s cold there... it’s dark there... ANUNCIATA extricates her hand and hurries away from the b leaving YOUNG PHILOMENA frightened, distraught...

Other inmates of Roscrea, ‘fallen’ YOUNG GIRLS like Philomena, a couple of them obviously pregnant, kneel by their beds in prayer. They are watched over by MOTHER BARBARA, mid-50s, kind-faced, the most senior nun at Rosc From upstairs they can hear PHILOMENA crying out in pain; see how frightened the YOUNG GIRLS are, some in tears.
(Soothing voice) Pray girls. Pray for the Magdalen. As they whisper their prayers ANUNCIATA enters the dormit and hurries up to MOTHER BARBARA.

Reverend Mother, please - we must get a doctor. The baby is the wrong way round, it’s breech.  10. MOTHER BARBARA is aware the YOUNG GIRLS are listening intently. In that same, soothing voice, she replies:
It’s in God’s hands now. Now we see the hardness in her, the darkness of her eyes. MOTHER BARBARA (cont'd) The pain is her penance. It will help absolve her of her sin.

YOUNG PHILOMENA thrashes about, delirious. The OLDER NUNS do no more than press wet cloths to her head. ANUNCIATA enters, looks at YOUNG PHILOMENA in such pain. sees again the forceps on the side and cries out in angui

I don’t know how to do it! Mother Barbara’s words are in her head... ‘it’s in God’s hands now’... but she cannot do it - she cannot just stan and let the girl die. She picks up the forceps and plunge between YOUNG PHILOMENA’S legs. On the girl’s scream..

INT. MOTHER BARBARA'S STUDY, ROSCREA -— DAY Jump back to two months earlier. YOUNG PHILOMENA stands before MOTHER BARBARA and YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE, Mother Barbara’s number two, thin-faced, early 40s. Ashamed of h swollen, pregnant belly, she can barely meet their eyes.
Did you let him put his hands on you?
(Beat, humiliated) Yes sister.
And did you enjoy that? Did you enjoy your sin? YOUNG PHILOMENA doesn’t answer.
Did you take your knickers down? YOUNG PHILOMENA looks at the two older women, their eyes boring into her. She is too petrified to answer.  11.
Answer Sister Hildegarde - did you take them down?
(Tears in her eyes) Yes. YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE settles back into her chair, turn sniffily to Mother BARBARA:
He got an awful lot for his toffee apple.
Oh Reverend Mother the sisters at school never told us anything about babies or... the thing.
Did your mother not tell you?
Her mother died ten years ago.
Oh, God rest her soul... (Sudden venom) But don’t dare to blame the sisters! You are the cause of this shame. You and your indecency!

Back to the birth. With the forceps and her strong finger ANUNCIATA pushes and twists the tiny body inside YOUNG PHILOMENA, lying back, drenched in sweat, moaning in pain Finally, with a gush of pale red liquid onto the white sh ANUNCIATA pulls out the baby’s head, dragging a new life God's world. It’s over and ANUNCIATA, overcome with emoti holds up the newborn baby to his mother.
It’s a boy. She hands him to YOUNG PHILOMENA, who takes him to her ch
I knew. Caption: Roscrea, 1952 The door to the delivery room opens. MOTHER BARBARA stand the doorway, taking in the sight of YOUNG PHILOMENA cradl her baby. She makes the sign of the cross.  12.
Thank the Lord. Aware of MOTHER BARBARA’S icy glare but bitter at her hypocrisy, ANUNCIATA is forced to also make the sign.
EXT. MARION’S HOUSE - NIGHT To establish a white stucco-fronted Georgian town house, bathed in the golden sun of late evening. SFX sounds of a party from inside.

INT. MARION’S HOUSE - NIGHT A drinks party at a central London town house, an informa gathering for journalists and New Labour types. WAITRESSE serving drinks to GUESTS. JANE, worried, is serving canapes (or maybe she is going round with bottles of wine topping up glasses). And now w REVEAL behind her MARTIN, looking ill at ease, wishing he wasn’t there. DAVID, an old friend, same age, chatting wi KEITH, 50s, and a woman, 40s, a no-nonsense look about he (SALLY MITCHELL).
Martin! MARTIN forces a smile and joins them. DAVID (cont'd) (Gestures to KEITH) Keith you know. (Then to SALLY) Sally Mitchell this is Martin Sixsmith, used to be the BBC’s man in Moscow.
And Washington.

And then became a spin doctor for the government, until it all went a bit tits up. Is that a fair summation Martin? DAVID is not drunk but has obviously had a few drinks. JANE, serving, is all ears.  13.
Yes. Pretty much. I suppose if you shovel shit for long enough, you'll end up with some on your shoes. They laugh politely.
Yeh but you got it on your head - how did you manage that? They laugh louder - MARTIN too.
Yes, well, you’ve got to have a sense of humour about these things.
What are you up to at the moment?
I’m thinking of writing a book. On Russian history. .? They look at him and no-one responds. Horrible eggy momen MARTIN (cont'd) Or something else. Might try going back to journalism-
I remember you! You’re the one who sent that terrible e-mail saying-
No I didn’t. Common mistake.
(Line overlaps with his) -it was a good day to bury bad news on 9/11... I thought that was you?

No, that was someone else. What I actually did was, one year later, on the day of Princess Margaret's funeral, send an e-mail saying let’s make sure the only thing we ‘bury’ today - inverted commas - is Princess Margaret.
Which is slightly different.  14.

It’s totally different. But the papers said it was another e-mail about burying bad news, nobody from the government defended me and... I got royally fucked up the arse by a bunch of self interested spineless shits.
(Sarcastic) But you’ve still got a sense of humour about it?
(Defiantly) Yes.
Well if you want to get back into journalism, talk to Sally.

Oh I just do, you know, sob stories, human interest stuff - not really your cup of tea is it. MARTIN looks at her awkwardly. It isn’t, but he doesn’t w to say it isn’t. SALLY (cont'd) But I’1l be happy to have a look if you want to push any ideas my way?
Yes... please. To escape his embarrassment he walks over to JANE, standi close by. MARTIN (cont'd) Could I get a glass of... Pinot Grigio please? JANE is obviously not in the mood for niceties:
It’s just red or white.
Oh yes, sorry. White then please. But as she pours it, there is the first glimmer of recognition. She’s sure she’s seen Martin before.  15.
I hope you don’t mind me asking but didn't you used to be a reporter on News At Ten?
Erm, I was the BBC’S correspondent yes, in Moscow and then Washington.

I know a woman, you see, and she had a baby when she was a teenager and she kept it a secret for fifty years - we only found out about it today. And the baby was taken from her by these nuns and they made her have it adopted. And she kept it a secret all this time... (Beat) It’s my mother.
Yes I guessed.
Would that be of any interest you to you - that kind of thing?
Well, I’m actually quite busy writing a book at the moment.
What about?
Russian history... (On her glazed reaction) -which is actually fascinating. And what you’re talking about is a human interest story, which I don’t really do.
Why not? He sees, at the other end of the kitchen, SALLY MITCHELL, DAVID and KEITH laughing with some other GUESTS.

Because human interest tends to be a euphemism for stories about vulnerable, weak-minded, ignorant, people to fill up the pages of newspapers read by vulnerable, weak- minded, ignorant people. (Suddenly realising how this sounds) (MORE)
MARTIN (cont'd) Not that you are and, um, I hope you find him... He takes his wine and walks off, taking a swig. JANE look totally nonplussed.
Taking his doctor’s words to heart MARTIN, up with the la jogs along a deserted street in a faded old ‘Spartak Mosc football jersey and shorts (from his time there), and bra new white trainers.

A recital. A congregation watches a choir singing John Taverner’s ‘Mother of God’; music fills the beautiful interior. MARTIN sits with wife KATE, petite, pretty, Scottish. Next to her is ROBERT, Martin’s doctor, and his wife. Whilst everyone else appears to be enjoying the mus MARTIN is fidgety and distracted, unable to take comfort pleasure from it.
SFX: the music continues over: MARTIN is now outside; a thoughtful, profile shot, breath condensing in the cold air.

MARTIN sits on the edge of his bed in his boxers and a T- Shirt. Behind him his wife KATE finishes moisturizing her hands before taking her dressing gown off and getting int bed. All the while we stay on MARTIN, wrestling with hims KATE gets into bed and sees that MARTIN has become frozen

(Finally) I don’t believe in God. And I don’t know when I stopped. A beat, then KATE makes her way over to his side of the b realising that her husband is deeply unhappy. She puts he arms around him from behind, comforting him.  17. MARTIN (cont'd) And I don’t know why it bothers me... Should I do a human interest story?

CLOSE UP on an overweight mobile phone SALESMAN picking through some ribs. Amongst other lunch time customers, al whom are very probably not interested in Russian history, FIND MARTIN standing waiting in the reception area, watch with faint disgust as the phone SALESMAN licks his finger MARTIN looks out of the entrance doors, his face reflecte the glass. He looks at his watch, ponders on why he’s her and not at all sure it’s a good idea. He glances out of t doors again... and he sees her. PHILOMENA, walking across car park towards him, JANE by her side. His ghostly reflection in the glass is super-imposed over her for a moment... Curiosity aroused, he strains to get a good look - but ge only intermittent glimpses as a couple cars drive past on their way out of the car park. He notes she’s dressed sma - presumably for his benefit - and looks nervous. As she finally enters the restaurant he smiles and steps forward greet her:
Hello I’m Martin, you must be Philomena.
Hello Martin. They shake hands; he notes the crucifix around her neck, in turn sneaks a look at him as he greets JANE.

(To JANE) Hello again. He gestures into the restaurant. MARTIN (cont'd) Table’s through here... He starts to lead them towards their table. MARTIN (cont'd) (To JANE) Sorry if I was a little rude the other night, caught me at a bad moment...  18.
I’m just glad you managed to track me down. Hope you didn’t mind meeting here but it’s mum’s favourite.
Oh no it’s... nice. They all sit down. MARTIN (cont'd) So how are you Philomena?
I’m all right. I had a new hip last year Martin, it’s much better than the bone one I had before and it’s made of ti-tanium which is metal - but it doesn’t rust.
Well if that happened you’d have to have it oiled like the Tin Man wouldn’t you.
Oh is that right?
No no - I mean, like the Wizard of Oz. PHILOMENA turns to JANE.
What does he mean?
He’s just joking mum.
It was just a joke. No, actually my mother has advanced osteoarthritis in both her knees. PHILOMENA laughs out loud. JANE realises that Martin is n now joking - and tries to move the whole thing on.
Shall we get some salad?
MARTIN and PHILOMENA are at one end of the salad bar, JAN the other.  19.
Jane's the clever one in our family. She went to university as a mature student - you know, when you're quite old. Where did you go Martin - Oxbridge I’1l bet.
Oxford yes.
I could tell you weren’t a duffer.
(Helping himself to some salad) Been a while since I’ve been in a Harvester.
Do they not have them in London?
No I tend to go to a little local place, near where I live.
And where’s that?
Knightsbridge.
Oh well that’1l be expensive. She sprinkles some bacon bits and croutons on her salad. Suddenly, PHILOMENA (cont'd) I like these little bits of toast on mine... (Beat) And are you married Martin?
Yes. I am. I have a wife, Kate.
Well that’s good. That’s grand... PHILOMENA reaches out and puts her hand on his. PHILOMENA (cont'd) I did love him, you know...
INT. BABIES’ DORMITORY - DAY (FORMERLY SCENE 22) A long line of babies in cots. Two NUNS tend over them.

I disappeared from the world. My family didn’t visit me, and out of shame my father told everyone that I was dead. After you’d had your baby you had to stay in the Abbey for four years, totally cut off from the outside world. In order to repay the sisters for taking you in, you had to work. The sheer number of infants, their cots lined up with military precision, drives home the message about Roscrea that it is a place that deals in babies.

INT. LAUNDRY, ROSCREA —- DAY The Abbey laundry; swirling steam, clattering noise. Watc over by YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE and two other NUNS, ‘fall GIRLS work loading clothing and bedding into boiling tubs water; or put wet laundry through huge mangles then hang out to dry on overhead lines.

The worst jobs were in the laundry, and that’s where they put me. I worked there seven days a week, the whole time I was there. They took in washing from miles around and charged for the service. We weren't paid a penny. I worked there with my best friend Kathleen. We find YOUNG PHILOMENA amongst them, dressed in a shapel pinafore, working over a boiling tub. Next to her is KATHLEEN, a pale faced young woman of roughly the same ag It's arduous, physically demanding work and YOUNG PHILOME and KATHLEEN, though worn out, try to keep each other’s spirits up with smiles of encouragement.
YOUNG PHILOMENA, KATHLEEN and three other GIRLS from the laundry, having finished their shift, hurry along a corri They pass Mother BARBARA, going in the opposite direction
We were allowed to see our children for an hour a day, that was all.
Walk don’t run! The GIRLS immediately slow, walking round the next corner

The girls come into the nursery, walk towards camera. Big smiles on their faces, they crouch and hold their arms ou As we HOLD on them, FROM BEHIND CAMERA, five little CHILD aged between two and three, rush past us into their mothe arms. We pick out YOUNG PHILOMENA... her little boy ANTHO dark-haired, now three - the same age as the photo - runs into her arms. She hugs him tight, swinging him around, totally in love.

INT. DAY NURSERY, ROSCREA — DUSK A little later. YOUNG PHILOMENA is sitting with KATHLEEN. They watch ANTHONY flying a toy aeroplane and holding the hand of Kathleen’s little daughter MARY, aged two, as the walk about together. The little girl reaches to take Anthony’s aeroplane and he lets her, without protest. She flies it about, just like he did.

Anthony was best friends with Kathleen’s daughter Mary - he’d even let her fly his little toy aeroplane. True love! The two of them were inseparable. The MOTHERS and CHILDREN are watched over by ANUNCIATA an another NUN, sitting together. YOUNG PHILOMENA and ANUNCI exchange a secret smile - but she can’t talk to her whils the other NUN is there, it’s not allowed.
(to KATHLEEN) Look at that, he won’t let her out of his sight. KATHLEEN doesn’t answer; YOUNG PHILOMENA sees she is anxi worried.  22.
What’s the matter?

(In a sudden rush) Oh Phil the girls in the kitchen said Mother Barbara had Mary up at the house today - what do you think she wanted with her? YOUNG PHILOMENA’S turns this over in her mind, but presen comforting face to her KATHLEEN.
I’m sure it’s nothing to worry about Kath.
We lived with it every day. Who’s child would be taken next? YOUNG PHILOMENA sees the other NUN leave the room, and se the opportunity to go and talk to ANUNCIATA.
(To KATHLEEN) I won’t be a minute. She goes over to ANUNCIATA , sits down next to her and ta in a quiet voice:

Kathleen’s worried sick. She thinks they’re going to take Mary away from her. I said if they were going to do that they’d tell her first for sure... ANUNCIATA is caught between a rock and a hard place. She’ just a young girl herself, and she doesn’t know how to de with the enormity of what she knows will happen to most o the girls at the abbey. So she clumsily tries to move the conversation on, and pulls something from her robe.

(Keeping her voice down) I got something for you Phil, but you can’t tell anyone about it. She hands YOUNG PHILOMENA a small, black and white photograph. She gasps: it is of Anthony, clutching his aeroplane, looking shyly at the camera.
He’s growing up so fast.
Oh thank you...  23. ANUNCIATA (cont'd) I'll bet his father was handsome.
He was. How did you... [GET THIS]
(Beat) I borrowed a Box Brownie and took it when Reverend Mother wasn’t looking.

PHILOMENA, now at the table with MARTIN and JANE, holds t same photo, the one Jane saw her clutching the night she finally confessed all, now in a small leather case. PHILO passes it to MARTIN, who studies it.

Whenever I look at that, I think about Anthony but I say a little prayer for Anunciata, who saved his life when I gave birth to him. She died a long time ago... if she hadn’t taken that, I’d have nothing.
So... you were just trapped there the whole time?
The only way you could leave was if you paid them a hundred pounds. But where would I get that kind of money? And where would I go? On PHILOMENA, we...
YOUNG PHILOMENA is back at work in the laundry.

It happened about a week later. I remember that day so clearly. As she starts to heave a heavy laundry bag over to a tub hears, outside, SFX tyres crunching on gravel. At this so the GIRLS exchange looks, a feeling of dread settling ove them. KATHLEEN starts to shake with fear.  24.

We all knew what it meant when a big car arrived. Kathleen was inconsolable. She knew this time they’d come for Mary. YOUNG PHILOMENA looks around and sees that, temporarily, YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE and one of the other nuns have disappeared - there is only one NUN left, who has her bac her. YOUNG PHILOMENA abandons her duties and crosses to a small basement window high up in the wall. Standing on tiptoes, she sees, beyond a hedge, a dreaded shiny black limousine drive past. KATHLEEN looks up at her piteously, pleadingly. YOUNG PHILOMENA catches the eye of another GI who shakes her head - ‘Don’t do it...’ - but ignores her checking that the NUN is still distracted, quickly darts through a back door.

YOUNG PHILOMENA emerges alone into a small courtyard, cro to the far side and peers through some gates fencing her from the outside world. Foliage half obscures some well- heeled FIGURES getting out of the limousine - a thirty- something woman in a fur coat and a man in a Cashmere coa and Homburg hat.

As soon as I saw their lovely clothes, and Mother Barbara so happy and smiling, I knew all hope was gone. She watches as they are greeted at the main entrance by a fawning and uncharacteristically gregarious Mother BARBAR Then, from behind:
Come away from there! She turns, scalded, and there is YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE.
What are you doing out here?
I... I had a stomach ache, Sister Hidegarde. It’s my time of the month.
Well... you’re not unique in that regard. Put your mind to your work and it’1l pass.  25. PHILOMENA retreats miserably to the laundry - she now kno all hope has gone for Kathleen.
Later that afternoon. YOUNG PHILOMENA is buttoning up her pinafore as she stands at a window.
Kathleen cried so hard they took her to the sick bay and gave her brandy. But her fate was sealed. YOUNG PHILOMENA looks down through the window and we...

.+. her POV. From her vantage point she looks down across courtyard, through a window, into the nursery. She can se little MARY but, because of the angle she is looking down from and the height of the window frame, she can only see bottom halves of four adults who surround the little girl Mother BARBARA and YOUNG SISTER HILDEGARDE - identifiable from their unflattering skirts and shoes - are presenting MARY to the couple we saw earlier, the woman recognizable from her fur coat and heels; the man from his pressed trousers and polished shoes. MARY looks up at them wide-e frightened.

This’ll save your hip.  53. She’s holding her book, a romantic novel entitled ‘The Slipper And The Horseshoe’, in her hands. She sees him pu his book - a weighty tome about Tsar Nicholas - out from shoulder bag.
Is that an interesting book Martin - I’ve just finished mine. She brandishes ‘The Slipper And The Horseshoe’.
It’s er... about Tsarist Russia and the October revolution and... it’s a bit dull you know, it’s all just political horse-trading really...

Mine was about horses too. It was about this fella Robert and he’s engaged to this duchess and he’s the son of a doctor so he’s done very well for himself but this woman oh she’s terrible this duchess is vain as you like and forever looking in the mirror and all the rest of it. And she thinks he’s dull as ditch-water so he takes up an interest in the horses so he fits in with all the upper classes and well of course he meets the girl down the stables and she’s not even a doctor’s daughter her father’s just a farmhand and he only has one foot but anyway of course they fall in love, so the duchess you’re thinking be careful what you wish for and he’s now torn between becoming a duke because when he marries her he’ll become lord of the manor and all that sort of thing, and the stable girl who he loves but hasn’t a penny to her name her brothers have no shoes on their feet.
(Trying to cut in) That sounds great.
The vehicle rounds a corner; PHILOMENA is still in full f MARTIN trapped next to her.  54.

-so the big day’s coming, the wedding and she, oh she’s a lovely, lovely girl, she says Robert has to do his duty and he’s spoken for and of course he’s being measured up for his suit but you can tell his heart’s not in it he’s all the while thinking about the horses and the stable girl. And they’re all there waiting for him in the church, the hoi polloi, but the thing is Martin this duchess she just wants Robert to spite the fella she’s really after but towards the end the duchess finds out that the stable girl has designs on Robert and the father without the foot dies but before he does he says to Robert ‘follow your heart’ and then the duchess gives the stable girl her marching orders and she packs her things - there’s a pony and trap waiting for her outside and when she climbs into it she asks do you know where we’re going? And the driver turns round and if it isn’t yer man Robert. And he says ‘I’m taking you to a place where no-one can hurt you anymore’.

WIDE SHOT: the buggy sails on serenely towards the gate, PHILOMENA and MARTIN getting smaller in frame as they get further and further away. PHILOMENA (cont‘d) Well, I didn’t see that coming Martin, not in a million years.
No... no it’s nice to have a surprise. Sounds like a real page turner.
You can borrow it.
Oh no really-
Come on I’ve just finished it now.  55.
(Weakly) -I almost feel like I’ve read it.
PHILOMENA and MARTIN sit together as PASSENGERS board all around them. A HOSTESS offers them a tray of drinks.
Champagne or Buck’s Fizz?
No thank you.
(Following his lead) No thank you. The HOSTESS moves on. MARTIN tips PHILOMENA off:
They’re free.

(Immediately calls out) I say! I'll have a Buck's Fizz! The HOSTESS turns back to her and she takes a Buck’s Fizz PHILOMENA (cont’d) Thank you. (Takes a sip) Oo, that’s lovely. (To MARTIN, impressed) You have to pay for everything on Ryan Air.

Martin! MARTIN looks up and sees he’s been spotted by ALEX, (smar dressed slightly younger than Martin), who’s standing in First Class Cabin putting something in the overhead locke He walks through to Club World to say hello.
(Awkward) Alex, how are you?
Not seen you since you... left the department. I was gonna call you actually... ALEX'S eyes flick across to PHILOMENA, wondering who she  56. ALEX (cont'd) Still friends?
Yes of course.
Listen, I hope you didn’t think I dropped you in it?
Honestly, it doesn’t matter - fog of war.
Yeh, collateral damage. (Beat) So what are you up to - off to the primaries? ALEX looks again at PHILOMENA who is waiting, looking slightly confused, to be introduced.
Yeh-
No - he’s helping me look for my-
(Cutting her off) -it’s a human interest story. Human interest...

(Sensing the awkwardness) Oh. Well good luck with it... I'd better scoot back. ALEX goes back into the First Class Cabin, MARTIN smiling until he’s out of sight - then the smile disappears. PHILOMENA leans across.
I’m sorry Martin should we pretend we don’t know each other?
No no it’s just him, he’s a nosy... nuisance. She thinks about this, then points:
Is that First Class in there?  57.
(Slightly acid) Yes. It’s a perk of the job.
Just because you’re in first class it doesn’t make you a first class person.
He’s all right... A long pause, PHILOMENA takes a sip of her Buck’s Fizz, MARTIN opens his book. She leans in again, speaks quietly
I think he needs a good smack in the chops. MARTIN laughs.
I think you're probably right.
Several hours into the flight. MARTIN is dozing with his blanket over him; most of the other passengers are asleep too. PHILOMENA catches her reflection in the window and w

STILL NO SOUND. 1966. A school production of ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’. MICHAEL, (Anthony), now 14, is up on stag playing ‘Puck’. This is a different, more confident MICHA heavily made up, dancing around on stage in a loin cloth; so confident, authoritative, obviously loving it. We will realise later that he is exploring his sexuality. On stage, TITANIA, LYSANDER and HERMIA sleep. Enter PUCK.

Through the forest have I gone. But Athenian found I none, On whose eyes I might approve This flower's force in stirring love. Night and silence.--Who is here? Weeds of Athens he doth wear: This is he, my master said, Despised the Athenian maid; And here the maiden, sleeping sound, On the dank and dirty ground. (MORE)

MICHAEL (AS PUCK) (cont'd) Pretty soul! she durst not lie Near this lack-love, this kill courtesy. Churl, upon thy eyes I throw All the power this charm doth owe. When thou wakest, let love forbid Sleep his seat on thy eyelid: So awake when I am gone; For I must now to Oberon. PUCK exits.
Wheels hit the tarmac.

The seatbelt sign is switched off with a ‘ping’. PASSENGE jump up out of their seats and start to grab their bags f the overhead lockers. PHILOMENA gets up too, but MARTIN s seated - engrossed in ‘The Slipper and the Horseshoe’.
Martin can you help me with my bag? (No answer) Martin?
(Without looking up) One second... He wants to finish his page.
In the distance the Capitol. A taxi pulls into the Hotel forecourt.
Martin and Philomena enter the hotel.
MARTIN makes his way along the corridor to pay a visit on Philomena in her room. He finds the right room number and knocks. PHILOMENA answers, excited, and welcomes him in:
Martin, did you have a chocolate on your pillow?
INT. PHILOMENA’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT She leads him over to the balcony:
I did.
How the other half live, eh? They walk out onto the balcony and she gestures to a nigh time view of the city. PHILOMENA (cont'd) And look at that view.

Mine is of the heating ducts... His phone rings; he checks the display and takes the call MARTIN (cont'd) Oo - Caroline from the records office. He stays out on the balcony and PHILOMENA comes back insi to give him some privacy. As he paces up and down outside the phone, PHILOMENA sits on the bed and presses a few buttons - ending in an on-screen movie menu. She puts her glasses on and flicks through the movie summaries, gettin more and more impressed as she reads them. Finally, MARTI comes back in from the balcony. He looks around for some wood to touch - but can’t see an MARTIN (cont'd) Shall we go for a walk, try and shake off our jet lag? You said you wanted to see the Lincoln Memorial?
Well, we can go to see Mr. Lincoln. Or, we could watch on my television... (Reads from the screen) ‘Big Momma’s House’. (MORE)

PHILOMENA (cont'd) It’s about a little black man who pretends to be a fat black lady. They showed a little bit and they’re all chasing after him - it looked hilarious Martin. She looks up at MARTIN, expectantly.
They are two tiny figures gazing up at the great man.
Isn’t he wonderful. I’ve always wanted to see him in his big chair.
Well he was big man. Literally. Six foot four. Tallest American president.
I can see that. He’s tall even sitting down. They both fall silent for a moment.
They set off down the steps. MARTIN is lining up a photo of PHILOMENA with Lincoln in background.
«+. I had a friend and her daughter paid for her to go to Florida for her seventieth birthday and she said ‘Phil, the size of the portions - you wouldn’t believe’.
Stop there. I’m going to take your photograph. He gets out his camera. He fiddles with a setting.
Is this for the article?  61.
Erm, yeh.
Only I’m a little bit worried you see, because if I find him he might be very disapproving of talking to the papers. Families are very private things.
(Half distracted, fiddling with camera) Well, yes, that’s true, but tracking him down’s a very expensive business so it’s a sort of quid pro quo...
What does that mean?
It means you don’t get something for nothing. He’s happy with the camera now and lines up the shot agai MARTIN (cont'd) I won't write anything you're unhappy with. Just the truth.
That's the thing I’m worried about. A beat. She feels she has no option but to go along with PHILOMENA (cont’d) Should I smile or should I be serious?

Let’s do one happy, one not so happy, then we’re covered. (Poised to take it) Ready... PHILOMENA smiles, he takes the snap. She changes to a wor expression and he takes another snap. MARTIN (cont'd) Great.

text: PHILOMENA is working her way steadily through a huge hotd with onions and fries.  62.

-if you want chips here, by the way Martin, you have to ask for French Fries. Because if you ask for chips they’1l just bring you crisps. (Thinks about this) And if you ask for crisps... well, I don’t know what they’1l bring you.
(Jet-lagged, just wanting to go to bed) Yes, it can be very confusing. PHILOMENA takes a thoughtful bite of her hotdog.

I’m getting scared... now we’re getting closer. (Beat) All these years, wondering whether Anthony was in trouble, or in prison... or goodness knows what. As long as I didn’t know, I could always tell myself that he was happy somewhere, and he was doing all right. She starts to get really upset. PHILOMENA (cont’d) But what if he died in Vietnam? Or came back with no legs, or lived on the street...

(Gently) Well... no point upsetting yourself. We don’t know what we don’t know. We’ll just have to deal with that when we get there. She nods. Takes a slurp of her milk shake. They are further away, walking near some trees.
What if he was a drug addict Martin, or... what if he was obese?
(Incredulous) Obese?  63.
I watched this documentary that said a lot of Americans are huge - what if that’s happened to him?
But... what on earth makes you think he’d be obese?
(Tearful) Well, because of the size of the portions... They walk away under the trees.
MARTIN escorts PHILOMENA back to her room.
Night Philomena, if you need me just dial 7, and then my room number 524.
7524. Okay, good night Martin, and thank you. Oh - would you like some biscuits because they gave me two in a little packet and I don’t want them.
No, thank you.
Well if you change your mind just call me - what do you dial?
I dial 7534 for your room.
If you need them just call 7534 and I‘1l bring them round to you.
I won’t. But thank you.
Good night Martin.
Good night.  64. She closes the door.

(Previously Sc. 69) NOW WE HAVE SOUND. Mid-80s. A track plays - ‘Doot Doot’ b Freur, as a POV shot, grainy early video, takes us throug packed ‘Studio 54’ type place, full of beautiful 80s peop lots of neon, flashing lights, wild hair styles, women wi bright lipstick and avant garde outfits. CLUBBERS part, smiling, as the camera ploughs between the whoever is shooting this wants to capture as many faces a memories of that night as possible. They react to the cam video cameras are a novelty. We hear snatches of conversation, high spirits. Finally the camera reaches a group of men and women in their 20s and 30s, including MA WELLER, late 20s, back-combed dark hair, bright lipstick. there in the middle of everyone is MICHAEL, now mid-30s, smiling, enigmatic. He speaks to the guy behind the camer

Hey Pete... MARCIA plants a kiss on MICHAEL’S cheek and gives the cam a smouldering look as they both ‘pose’ for the camera. Th scene tells us that Anthony/Michael has grown into a youn man with a louche, cool private life.

The still image of a nun, wearing bright red lipstick, ey closed in ecstasy, her bare breasts covered by the hands another topless nun behind her wearing only a wimple. We REVEAL MARTIN has dozed off, fully clothed, on his bed, T remote on his stomach. The room phone rings, he wakes wit start and picks it up.

Hello? (Listens ) No... no I’ve got a bath robe Philomena. (Listens ) Yes, there are two in every room. And the slippers. (Listens) Thanks, see you in the morning. He hangs up, looks at the image of the nun, then checks h watch. Time to call home. He picks up his mobile and dial waits for a connection.  65. MARTIN (cont'd) Hello sweetheart, how’s everyone? He puts her onto speaker as he settles back onto the bed pours himself a miniature brandy over ice, takes a sip.
We’re all good, Danny won his rugby match today and he nearly scored a try. How’s Philomena?

(Big sigh) Well, I have now seen, first hand, what a lifetime’s diet of Reader’s Digest, the Daily Mail and romantic novels can do to a person’s brain. I don’t know who I want to strangle first - Mills or Boon. KATE laughs. MARTIN (cont'd) She keeps telling all the hotel staff how kind they are - she must think they’re volunteers. She met four people today who were all, ‘one in a million’. What are the chances of that?
Oh come on she’s just a little old Irish lady. He finishes off his brandy.
What are you wearing?
Um... fleecy pyjamas, bed socks and men’s slippers.
Nice.
What are you doing?
Lying on the bed going through the movie menu.
Anything worth watching?  66.
There’s one called ‘Naughty Habits’. ‘Forbidden pleasures of the flesh from behind convent walls’.
Do they look like the nuns at Roscrea?
No. I think these ones are a little more... charitable.
The still of the slutty nuns on screen.
INT. PHILOMENA’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT PHILOMENA comes out of the bathroom in her full length nightie, kneels by the bed and says her prayers, then get bed and turns the light out.

(Previously Sc 66) 1982. Poor quality, taped VHS of news footage of a photo opportunity at the White House; President REAGAN is surrounded by ADVISORS. He turns to shake hands with the to his right; we see that it’s MICHAEL, smiling nervously undeniably thrilled to be amongst such illustrious compan We now see he is a man with what appears to be a stellar career in the making. But his appearance - conservative career-man - is totally at odds with the night-clubber we in scene 66. FADE TO BLACK.

INT. MARTIN’S ROOM, WASHINGTON DC HOTEL - NIGHT MARTIN has fallen asleep on his bed still fully clothed. Woken by his door buzzer, he rouses himself and answers i He looks through the spyhole and sees PHILOMENA outside i her dressing gown. He steels himself and opens the door.
Hello.  67.

Martin I wanted to tell you something earlier but it slipped my mind, and I was going to tell you on the phone but I forgot the number, so I thought I’d come and tell you in person what with you only being along the corridor.
Okay.

What I wanted to say was, thank you Martin, for helping me to look for my son. I know you got the sack from your job - not News At Ten - the other one. And I just want to say, that their loss is my gain.
(Stunned for a moment) Thank you.
Good night Martin.
Good night. She walks off. He shuts the door, not sure how to react.
Another of his morning constitutional jogs, to shake out jetlag. But there’s an unwelcome addition to the routine - other JOGGERS apparently much fitter than he. He chugs gamely.

MARTIN is sitting at a table, working at his laptop, sipp from a black coffee. The breakfast area is busy, and in f of him PHILOMENA is enjoying herself investigating what i offer at the hot buffet. CLOSE UP: the computer screen. MARTIN is working through long list of files; we see pictures of different males of varying ages, all named ‘Anthony’ or ‘Tony’ Lee. Some Christian names are spelt with a ‘h’, some without; some surnames spelt ‘Leigh’ or ‘Lea’. Each file is different, have a military appearance, some civil, some even appear be criminal records.  68. MARTIN looks up and sees PHILOMENA chatting with the CHEF the omelette station and overhears a snatch of conversati

-we don’t really have Mexicans in England, we have the Indians instead, and everybody loves curry. He returns to his laptop. He is checking the photos attac to the records; one is a cutting showing a blonde busines shaking hands with somebody; another is a young black boy another is a man in a marines uniform. MARTIN dwells on s but quickly rejects others. He dials a number on his mobi waits impatiently for it to go through:

Hi Caroline it’s Martin Sixsmith. Hi... (Listens ) Yes, I’m not getting any joy, but I just wanted to check - you know the file with the immigration cuttings? (Listens ) I know you’ve checked, but could you send me a link anyway? (Listens ) Thanks. He hangs up as PHILOMENA comes back over to the table, glancing briefly at the screen. MARTIN (cont'd) Morning.
Martin they’ve got pancakes over there, and waffles and omelettes - any filling - and cereals and bacon and sausage and-
Yeh I know what’s over there.
-anything you like. The breakfast is included isn’t it?
Yes, yes - I’m just not hungry. My stomach hasn’t woken up yet.
Mine wakes up before I do. I’m having a ham and Swiss cheese omelette - shall I get you one?
No thank you.  69.
Why don’t you have some blueberries?
(Anything to stop the relentless barrage) Okay, yes. Great. Now a WAITRESS approaches their table.
Coffee?
No thanks.
Okay if you want to help yourself to breakfast over there we have a hot and cold buffet, fresh fruit and cereal, muffins, omelettes with a choice of-
I know-
-fillings.
-I know exactly what is available for breakfast. So. Thank you.
(Trying to tempt him) We also have fresh pancakes?
(Sharply) No. Thank you. I’m trying to have a private conversation here.
My apologies sir. The WAITRESS leaves.
There’s no need to be rude. He’s a very kind man, Antonio.
Yes, I’m sure he’s one in a million - well one in a hundred thousand.
What do you mean?  70.
You've said that to at least ten people now - so that’s just maths.

You should be nice to people on the way up because you might meet them again on the way down. I’d have thought you of all people would understand that. This stings, though maybe she didn’t mean it to. And then again, maybe she did? PHILOMENA (cont’d) I’d rather you were rude to me than the nice people who work here.

I’m trying to help you find your son, that’s why we’re here. Okay? So, please- (Gestures to laptop) -just for now, can I have some quiet time? PHILOMENA looks at him, her nose defiantly up in the air. goes to say something but stops herself.

MARTIN is studying his laptop. He sees a new e-mail in hi inbox from ‘Owsianoska, Caroline’, entitled ‘Anthony Lee’ opens it and clicks on a link. As he waits for it to down he sees PHILOMENA back at the omelette station, and catch snippet of her renewed conversation with the CHEF.

-were you born in Mexico? Well you must like nachos? My grand daughter Natalie got me into them. I’ve never been to Mexico - I hear it’s lovely apart from the kidnappings- Shaking his head in exasperation, he turns back to the sc where an image downloads line by line from the top of the screen. We make out a blurry newspaper photo of a little and girl, holding hands with a smart, middle-aged couple posing at an airport arrivals lounge. MARTIN hears PHILOM share a laugh with the CHEF and is about to look over to when the image reveals the boy is holding a tin toy aerop in his hand. Stunned, he recognizes it instantly. He has found Anthony. The headline above the cutting reads: ‘New Life For Irish Orphans’.  71. Excited, he scans the article, picks up the surname Hess finds the boy’s Christian name: Michael. He puts ‘Michael Hess, D.O.B. 07.05.52’ into a search eng waits a few moments, then clicks on a site - the official site of the Republican Party. There is a picture of the a Michael, early 30s, smiling, in a formal head and shoulde pose. But it’s the passage at the top of the page which j him: Michael A. Hess: (b) 07.05.52 - (d) 08.15.95. He sta at the legend (d). Surely not..? Scarcely able to believe it, he scans the article below t picture, picks out some key sentences: ‘Michael was broug to the US from Ireland by his adoptive parents...’ and th at the end: ’... Michael died on August 15th, 1995.’ See MARTIN: Oh God, he’s dead... MARTIN looks up to see PHILOMENA making her way back to t table with her omelette and a bowl of raspberries. In a p he quickly shuts down the window showing the young Anthon clutching the aeroplane. PHILOMENA (cont’d) They’ve run out of blueberries so I got you raspberries instead. MARTIN just stares at her, frozen expression. She misinterprets this as an admonishment. PHILOMENA (cont’d) Oh, I’m sorry. Quiet time. As PHILOMENA puts down her tray she glances at the screen now just displaying the image of the adult Michael in the formal pose. She stares at it and, even though she can’t what Anthony would look like as a grown man, puts her han her chest. PHILOMENA (cont’d) That’s my Anthony. She looks at MARTIN, who doesn’t answer. But his eyes not only confirm this they tell her something else... she clutches her crucifix. PHILOMENA (cont'd) He’s dead... isn’t he.
(A beat then he whispers, choked) Yes. (Beat) I’m sorry. A WAITRESS hovers holding a coffee pot.  72.
Coffee? There’s no answer; the WAITRESS hovers, obviously unaware what is happening.
Coffee?
(Anguished) He doesn’t want coffee he wants blueberries! PHILOMENA starts to cry.

(To the WAITRESS) Thank you, we don’t need anything. MARTIN tries to comfort PHILOMENA, putting his arms round awkwardly, self-consciously, speaking quietly to her. MARTIN (cont'd) I’m so sorry... She readily accepts the comfort. SCORE: Music by BACH...

BACH CONTINUES over... We see PHILOMENA in the back of a taxi on the way to the airport, the lights of the city playing on her window. Sh numb, disengaged from all that’s going on around her. The taxi stops at some traffic lights.

BACH CONTINUES, building to a swell... PHILOMENA stares out at the PEOPLE in the street; she can understand how life is going on when Anthony is gone. She sees a YOUNG WOMAN picked up by her BOYFRIEND and swung r playfully as he gives her a kiss. He then pretends liftin her has hurt his back; she laughs. MARTIN looks across to PHILOMENA, not knowing what to say The lights change, the taxi pulls away.

PHILOMENA sits by herself on a row of chairs in the airpo lounge, this ‘cathedral’ to modern life. We see her in profile, staring inscrutably at something. She seems sudd old, bird like. Now we REVEAL what she’s looking at: a pi of iconography - a huge Calvin Klein poster in portrait aspect of a beautiful female model laughing in a casual embrace with a devastatingly handsome, be-stubbled male model. She wears a negligee, he wears a vest. They have perfect teeth. Perfect lives. They are shamelessly happy. SCORE ENDS.
PHILOMENA sits with MA SALLY (CONT'D) (cont'd) What did he die of?
I don’t know, I didn’t find out. We're at the airport now.
(Interrupts him) Wait - you’re at the airport?
Yeh. Obviously she wants to get back home, be with her daughter.
What about the story?
(Confused) Well... he’s dead. SALLY shakes her head curtly at the SUB EDITOR - she does like his layout.
Dead or alive, happy or sad - you said it - they’re both good. Spin it, find a story..
Yeh, but if I stay here and she goes, no-one’s going to answer my questions.
Then keep her there.  74.
What? Come on... she’s in bits. It’s like she’s lost him all over again.
That’s great - write that line down.
Are you serious?
Yes, you signed a contract. Call me when you've got something. She hangs up. MARTIN looks at PHILOMENA, sitting quietly, looking up at the poster. He feels a wave of terrible gui
MARTIN sits down next to PHILOMENA. A few moment’s silenc they both look up at the poster together; PHILOMENA stare the female model, laughing, carefree.

I remember that day at the fair, his father made me laugh by pretending to be an old man. (Smiles, remembering) And then I made him laugh by pretending to be an old lady. (Beat, the smile disappears) And now I am one... I’1l never know if Anthony ever thought about me. I’‘1l never be able to say sorry.
(Beat, not quite sure how to put it) Look, we don’t have to... (Voice tails off) We can... stay.
Stay?
If you want to?
What for? And now he must grit his teeth and begin the lie.  75.
I was thinking we could... maybe talk to some people who knew him, find out what happened to him?
I think I’d rather just go home. On Martin: so this is what it has come down to - forced t persuade an old lady to stay with him against her wishes, against his better judgement.
I... think it might help, in terms of your loss. She looks at him, unable to speak for a moment.
Will it?

There’s lot of research which suggests that... people who’ve suffered a loss can help... overcome it by talking to people who knew the person that died and, from them, learning about his life, sort of thing... A halting, inarticulate and wholly unconvincing attempt. didn’t even come close to convincing himself.
Really?
Yes.
I didn’t know that.
Yes it’s quite well known... I really think it could help. She nods, not really in any state to argue, and allows hi help her up. We can see from his face how shitty he feels
SCENE DELETED (Now Sc. 78A)

1988. MICHAEL and MARCIA are being walked by a REALTOR towards a house for sale;  76. PETE is behind the camera videoing them - we think they m very well be a young couple looking at a home to start a family in. The house itself is a sprawling, typically New England property set in large grounds.
What do you think?
It’s incredible... (Beat) What about you? She takes the camera from him, turns it on PETE.
Yeh, pretty cool. (Nods to MICHAEL) What about the lord of the manor? She now turns the camera on to MICHAEL.
I’ve fallen in love already...
MARTIN and PHILOMENA walk back up to the reception desk w their shoulder bags. The RECEPTIONIST recognizes them:
Hello, you're back again?
Yes... (Little bit embarrassed) ... change of plan.
(Checking display on her screen) We have the same rooms if you’d like them?
Um... okay. The RECEPTIONIST starts to enter information on her compu An awkward beat whilst she taps away at her keyboard.  77.
I suppose they’1ll just have to use the ‘not so happy’ photo...

They are back in Philomena’s old room. MARTIN is at a des tapping away at his laptop, PHILOMENA is sitting on a sof watching ‘Big Momma’s House’. MARTIN, uncomfortable with heavy emotion of the situation, looks across to her, sees has a glazed expression:
Are you okay?
I thought it would make me laugh. MARTIN tries to make some sense of what she’s watching.
Is that a man?
I don’t know.
I’ve been sent a picture of Anthony - do you want to see it?

Oh... (She thinks about this) Yes please. He offers her his chair; she gets up and walks over, sitt down in front of his laptop. She puts her glasses on and stares at the photo: it’s a wide, group shot with about twenty people in it, including Anthony and Marcia, at a formal function.
It's from a woman we’re meeting tomorrow called Marcia Weller, she was a colleague of Anthony’s... now shall we have a drink? He bends down by the mini-bar.
He looks very smart.
He worked in the legal department for the American government. Brandy isn’t it... (MORE)
MARTIN (cont'd) (Searching through mini- bar) Oh, they’re all gone.
Yes I had them earlier.
